title: Orion Threat Alert: Flight of the BumbleBee. A new campaign in the wild: BumbleBee

sentences: BumbleBee threat actors are not the first to change the initial access method from malicious office documents to malicious ISO image files. The ISO image file abuse was also seen a few years ago, but in recent months, we have observed an increase in ISO campaigns.
In this section, we will cover some interesting indicators and artifacts that highlighted the BumbleBee actions and heuristics. These artifacts also help us to identify the BumbleBee malware.
Hex-Editor shows 3 MZ headers: the first one is the Bumblebee, and the other two are additional payloads
After the initial execution, the BumbleBee DLL is copied to the %programdata%/{RandomDir} directory. In addition to the DLL, a VBS script is also dropped to the same directory:

The Orion team is constantly monitoring BumbleBee and the IAB groups activities closely and analyzing them to better understand their motivation. As we learn more, we will publish our findings and artifacts to share additional insights for BumbleBee infection to ransomware post-attack chain.
Orion, Cynets Threat Research and Intelligence team, spotted a new malware campaign in the wild: BumbleBee.
Example of the unique User-Agent: BumbleBee in the payloads memory
Copy of the BumbleBee DLL to %Programdata% directory
We detected a scheduled task execution during the BumbleBee infection:

Orion found a high number of targeted companies based in the US with the following distribution method that delivers the BumbleBee malware: Spear phishing email > URL Link (TransferXL, TransferNow, WeTransfer) > Zipped ISO > ISO (contains the LNK file and the BumbleBee payload).
In the image below, we found the BumbleBee internal name and export function inside the process Rundll32.exe that executed the BumbleBee DLL loader:

BumbleBee checks whether certain user names reside in the victims machine by comparing against a hardcoded list of user names. This allows BumbleBee to detect sandboxes and labs that are used for malware analysis:
After the initial execution, the BumbleBee process (Rundll32) communicated with the Command-and-Control server (C2). Weve seen several C2 servers from different IR cases:

Weve handled several incident response (IR) cases where threat actors distributed BumbleBee malware. After the initial infection, the threat actors inject Cobalt Strike shellcode in memory and execute discovery commands to collect info about the victims network. We believe that threat actors performed this data collection in order to execute the next stage of the infection.
In this post, we will cover what this campaign is, and how the IAB distributes the BumbleBee malware and its TTPs. We will also explain each TTP according to the MITRE ATT&CK model, and its purpose.
In our labs, we observed that BumbleBee uses several anti-VM methods to avoid detection.
PEStudio shows the unpacked Bumblebee section and highlighted the .data section
On April 12, 2022, the BumbleBee IAB group was spotted using IMG file format in addition to ISO file format.

Threat Analysis Group (TAG) shared observations on the financially motivated threat actor, EXOTIC LILY, that use the BumbleBee malware. In addition, TAG mentioned an interesting point of collaboration between EXOTIC LILY and the WIZARD SPIDER threat group.
BumbleBee internal name, export functions, and TimeDateStamp
The BumbleBee payload was delivered via a spear phishing email that was sent from a spoofed email address. The email contains a URL link to the legitimate public storage service, TransferXL.
The malware name, BumbleBee, was chosen because of its unique user agent, bumblebee, that was used as part of the communication with the command and control server (C2).
Strings from the BumbleBee loader show the VBS script and the execution method

Weve seen Living Off the Land Binaries (LOLBins) execution with rundll32, which allows threat actors to avoid defenses. BumbleBee also creates a scheduled task on the compromised host for persistence and executes a Visual Basic script via the scheduled task. The IAB relies on the user (victim) execution to execute the BumbleBee payload by luring the victim to mount an ISO image file and click on a Windows shortcut (LNK) file.

As part of the campaign, the threat actors abuse spoofed companies identities (like fake employee email addresses, fake websites, etc.) and use legitimate public storage services to deliver the malicious ISO image file. The ISO image file is responsible for luring the victim to execute the BumbleBee malware.
BumbleBee also detects if it is running within a VM by checking for known services that are related to different VM products:

From our initial analysis, BumbleBee is a custom new loader that is used by different IAB groups. This malware was observed injecting Cobalt Strike shellcodes in memory and using several tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) in order to compromise the victims environment.

We noticed a new trend in Initial Access Brokers (IAB) tactics to gain access to their victims machines. Initial Access Brokers refers to a cybercrime group that specializes in gaining initial access to organizations for the sole purpose of offering it to other threat actor groups. The trend started earlier this year and our team recently spotted their new BumbleBee campaign.
Strings from the Bumblebee loader show the WMI Win32_Process execution

BumbleBee payload<crlf>88F5AE9691E6BCDD4065A420EAFAF3E3AA32C69605BF564A42FFD8ECD25C9920<crlf>4a49e2f06ba48d3a88fdeb83fb8021f3d165535e8ea5319b16a7ebe4da9c0751<crlf>08cd6983f183ef65eabd073c01f137a913282504e2502ac34a1be3e599ac386b<crlf>186145f84ed6a473ec6bc4afa66bff156057888938793b12afd17659041ddbba<crlf>4063fab9176db3960fa6014173b6c7ba52f19424887f5a6205ff73aa447ada61<crlf>53b3ebaa3c485772f8e6abaa0f366ef192137496a7064e015ced4e6fc204b3c8<crlf>d74a3f9b35d657516eb53d4e70582f93d22077d3e0936758cc4ef76d5171075d<crlf>8f47c3962a7c418bae71fec42bbca9524b72f8f0fd2dd81d1175138f7d20b2f7<crlf>c97b8bffcbe424cbc2a6e1135068d071c6f4e8f020fccd2db3dbee3aa80102ac<crlf>BumbleBee C2 server<crlf>IP: 23.82.19[.]208 Port 443<crlf>IP: 192.236.198[.]63 Port 433<crlf>IP: 45.147.229[.]177 Port 433<crlf>Cobalt Strike C2 server<crlf>hojimizeg[.]com - 45.147.228[.]197<crlf>notixow[.]com - 23.19.58[.]154<crlf>rewujisaf[.]com - 142.234.157[.]176
Additional reference to the BumbleBee malware name

We have other artifacts from different IR cases, where we have observed the following activity. The screenshot below shows an event that detected a creation of a payload in the %ProgramData%\{Random} directory the DLL payload is a copy of the initial BumbleBee loader that executed by Rundll32 from the ISO image file:
By inspecting the unpacked BumbleBee sections, we discovered that the .data section contains two executables:
After unpacking the BumbleBee loader and by searching in the metadata of the unpacked payload, we identified BumbleBees internal name, LdrAddx64.dll, and two export functions IternalJob and SetPath.
titles: Orion Threat Alert: Flight of the BumbleBee
By: Max Malyutin Orion Threat Research Team Leader
Orion Threat Alert: Flight of the BumbleBee. A new campaign in the wild: BumbleBee
A new campaign in the wild: BumbleBee

sentences: From our initial analysis, BumbleBee is a custom new loader that is used by different IAB groups. This malware was observed injecting Cobalt Strike shellcodes in memory and using several tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) in order to compromise the victims environment.

Weve handled several incident response (IR) cases where threat actors distributed BumbleBee malware. After the initial infection, the threat actors inject Cobalt Strike shellcode in memory and execute discovery commands to collect info about the victims network. We believe that threat actors performed this data collection in order to execute the next stage of the infection.

sentences: Threat Analysis Group (TAG) shared observations on the financially motivated threat actor, EXOTIC LILY, that use the BumbleBee malware. In addition, TAG mentioned an interesting point of collaboration between EXOTIC LILY and the WIZARD SPIDER threat group.
titles: A new campaign in the wild: BumbleBee

sentences: Both DLL payloads have the same internal name RapportGP.dll. An interesting point regarding the payloads internal name is that there is a legitimate DLL named RapportGP.dll that is part of a Trusteer Ltd product from a computer security division of IBM.
Documents-17.iso (Bazarloader)

Different threat actors abuse ISO image files to deliver their payloads. For example, BazarISO deploys Bazarloader, and IcedID started to use ISO image files instead of MalDocs like in the two examples below.
Invoice_pdf_1.iso (IcedID)

Different threat actors abuse ISO image files to deliver their payloads. For example, BazarISO deploys Bazarloader, and IcedID started to use ISO image files instead of MalDocs like in the two examples below.

In most of the cases, weve seen that during different IR cases, the campaigns escalated to full-blown ransomware attacks. We believe that IAB groups work and collaborate with ransomware affiliates like CONTI, LockBit, AvosLocker, and more. For example, we observed an IcedID infection that leads to CONTI ransomware attack (Shelob Moonlight)..

In most of the cases, weve seen that during different IR cases, the campaigns escalated to full-blown ransomware attacks. We believe that IAB groups work and collaborate with ransomware affiliates like CONTI, LockBit, AvosLocker, and more. For example, we observed an IcedID infection that leads to CONTI ransomware attack (Shelob Moonlight)..

In most of the cases, weve seen that during different IR cases, the campaigns escalated to full-blown ransomware attacks. We believe that IAB groups work and collaborate with ransomware affiliates like CONTI, LockBit, AvosLocker, and more. For example, we observed an IcedID infection that leads to CONTI ransomware attack (Shelob Moonlight)..

In most of the cases, weve seen that during different IR cases, the campaigns escalated to full-blown ransomware attacks. We believe that IAB groups work and collaborate with ransomware affiliates like CONTI, LockBit, AvosLocker, and more. For example, we observed an IcedID infection that leads to CONTI ransomware attack (Shelob Moonlight)..

Usually, we observe malicious spam (MalSpam) campaigns that deliver malicious documents (MalDoc) to lure the victims to interact with the MalDoc and execute the malicious macro code by clicking Enable Content. That in turn downloads and executes the malicious payload, for example, the notorious Emotet campaigns.
titles: By: Max Malyutin Orion Threat Research Team Leader

sentences: From our initial analysis, BumbleBee is a custom new loader that is used by different IAB groups. This malware was observed injecting Cobalt Strike shellcodes in memory and using several tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) in order to compromise the victims environment.
Orion, Cynets Threat Research and Intelligence team, spotted a new malware campaign in the wild: BumbleBee.

Different threat actors abuse ISO image files to deliver their payloads. For example, BazarISO deploys Bazarloader, and IcedID started to use ISO image files instead of MalDocs like in the two examples below.

Orion found a high number of targeted companies based in the US with the following distribution method that delivers the BumbleBee malware: Spear phishing email > URL Link (TransferXL, TransferNow, WeTransfer) > Zipped ISO > ISO (contains the LNK file and the BumbleBee payload).

BumbleBee threat actors are not the first to change the initial access method from malicious office documents to malicious ISO image files. The ISO image file abuse was also seen a few years ago, but in recent months, we have observed an increase in ISO campaigns.

Threat Analysis Group (TAG) shared observations on the financially motivated threat actor, EXOTIC LILY, that use the BumbleBee malware. In addition, TAG mentioned an interesting point of collaboration between EXOTIC LILY and the WIZARD SPIDER threat group.
In this section, we will cover some interesting indicators and artifacts that highlighted the BumbleBee actions and heuristics. These artifacts also help us to identify the BumbleBee malware.
Additional reference to the BumbleBee malware name
The malware name, BumbleBee, was chosen because of its unique user agent, bumblebee, that was used as part of the communication with the command and control server (C2).

BumbleBee checks whether certain user names reside in the victims machine by comparing against a hardcoded list of user names. This allows BumbleBee to detect sandboxes and labs that are used for malware analysis:

We expected these groups to change the initial access methods. We believe there is a direct relation to the changes Microsoft applied recently to the default policy in their Office products: Macros from the internet will be blocked by default in Office and Excel 4.0 (XLM) macros are disabled by default. These changes impact IABs because they have been abusing Office documents with malicious macros for years.
Once they click download, the victim receives a ZIP folder that contains the malicious ISO image files.
Below youll see the legitimate public storage site, which leads the victim to the link to the malicious file.

As part of the campaign, the threat actors abuse spoofed companies identities (like fake employee email addresses, fake websites, etc.) and use legitimate public storage services to deliver the malicious ISO image file. The ISO image file is responsible for luring the victim to execute the BumbleBee malware.
Were expecting to see more malware campaigns that will use the ISO delivery method in the near future. So, stay vigilant.

Usually, we observe malicious spam (MalSpam) campaigns that deliver malicious documents (MalDoc) to lure the victims to interact with the MalDoc and execute the malicious macro code by clicking Enable Content. That in turn downloads and executes the malicious payload, for example, the notorious Emotet campaigns.
In this post, we will cover what this campaign is, and how the IAB distributes the BumbleBee malware and its TTPs. We will also explain each TTP according to the MITRE ATT&CK model, and its purpose.

Weve handled several incident response (IR) cases where threat actors distributed BumbleBee malware. After the initial infection, the threat actors inject Cobalt Strike shellcode in memory and execute discovery commands to collect info about the victims network. We believe that threat actors performed this data collection in order to execute the next stage of the infection.
titles: By: Max Malyutin Orion Threat Research Team Leader
A new campaign in the wild: BumbleBee

sentences: From our initial analysis, BumbleBee is a custom new loader that is used by different IAB groups. This malware was observed injecting Cobalt Strike shellcodes in memory and using several tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) in order to compromise the victims environment.

Weve handled several incident response (IR) cases where threat actors distributed BumbleBee malware. After the initial infection, the threat actors inject Cobalt Strike shellcode in memory and execute discovery commands to collect info about the victims network. We believe that threat actors performed this data collection in order to execute the next stage of the infection.
titles: A new campaign in the wild: BumbleBee

sentences: All the collected system and network information is sent to the C2 server, which sends back a response containing the next step/command to execute based on that info.

BumbleBee payload<crlf>88F5AE9691E6BCDD4065A420EAFAF3E3AA32C69605BF564A42FFD8ECD25C9920<crlf>4a49e2f06ba48d3a88fdeb83fb8021f3d165535e8ea5319b16a7ebe4da9c0751<crlf>08cd6983f183ef65eabd073c01f137a913282504e2502ac34a1be3e599ac386b<crlf>186145f84ed6a473ec6bc4afa66bff156057888938793b12afd17659041ddbba<crlf>4063fab9176db3960fa6014173b6c7ba52f19424887f5a6205ff73aa447ada61<crlf>53b3ebaa3c485772f8e6abaa0f366ef192137496a7064e015ced4e6fc204b3c8<crlf>d74a3f9b35d657516eb53d4e70582f93d22077d3e0936758cc4ef76d5171075d<crlf>8f47c3962a7c418bae71fec42bbca9524b72f8f0fd2dd81d1175138f7d20b2f7<crlf>c97b8bffcbe424cbc2a6e1135068d071c6f4e8f020fccd2db3dbee3aa80102ac<crlf>BumbleBee C2 server<crlf>IP: 23.82.19[.]208 Port 443<crlf>IP: 192.236.198[.]63 Port 433<crlf>IP: 45.147.229[.]177 Port 433<crlf>Cobalt Strike C2 server<crlf>hojimizeg[.]com - 45.147.228[.]197<crlf>notixow[.]com - 23.19.58[.]154<crlf>rewujisaf[.]com - 142.234.157[.]176
After the initial execution, the BumbleBee process (Rundll32) communicated with the Command-and-Control server (C2). Weve seen several C2 servers from different IR cases:
The malware name, BumbleBee, was chosen because of its unique user agent, bumblebee, that was used as part of the communication with the command and control server (C2).
In the strings we can see the C2 servers IP address and port
We analyzed the payload binary and noticed that this payload is responsible for communicating with BumbleBees C2 server:
titles: A new campaign in the wild: BumbleBee

sentences: The BumbleBee payload was delivered via a spear phishing email that was sent from a spoofed email address. The email contains a URL link to the legitimate public storage service, TransferXL.
Spear phishing email with a link to TransferXL

Orion found a high number of targeted companies based in the US with the following distribution method that delivers the BumbleBee malware: Spear phishing email > URL Link (TransferXL, TransferNow, WeTransfer) > Zipped ISO > ISO (contains the LNK file and the BumbleBee payload).

The Orion team is constantly monitoring BumbleBee and the IAB groups activities closely and analyzing them to better understand their motivation. As we learn more, we will publish our findings and artifacts to share additional insights for BumbleBee infection to ransomware post-attack chain.
The next stage is probably related to ransomware operations. Were still investigating IR cases in order to find conclusive evidence that the next stage delivers ransomware.

In most of the cases, weve seen that during different IR cases, the campaigns escalated to full-blown ransomware attacks. We believe that IAB groups work and collaborate with ransomware affiliates like CONTI, LockBit, AvosLocker, and more. For example, we observed an IcedID infection that leads to CONTI ransomware attack (Shelob Moonlight)..

Usually, we observe malicious spam (MalSpam) campaigns that deliver malicious documents (MalDoc) to lure the victims to interact with the MalDoc and execute the malicious macro code by clicking Enable Content. That in turn downloads and executes the malicious payload, for example, the notorious Emotet campaigns.
titles: By: Max Malyutin Orion Threat Research Team Leader

sentences: Threat Analysis Group (TAG) shared observations on the financially motivated threat actor, EXOTIC LILY, that use the BumbleBee malware. In addition, TAG mentioned an interesting point of collaboration between EXOTIC LILY and the WIZARD SPIDER threat group.
titles: A new campaign in the wild: BumbleBee

sentences: After unpacking the BumbleBee loader and by searching in the metadata of the unpacked payload, we identified BumbleBees internal name, LdrAddx64.dll, and two export functions IternalJob and SetPath.
In the image below, we found the BumbleBee internal name and export function inside the process Rundll32.exe that executed the BumbleBee DLL loader:
cmd.exe /c start rundll32 neqw.dll,IternalJob<crlf>rundll32.exe advpack.dll,RegisterOCX sysctl.exe

Both DLL payloads have the same internal name RapportGP.dll. An interesting point regarding the payloads internal name is that there is a legitimate DLL named RapportGP.dll that is part of a Trusteer Ltd product from a computer security division of IBM.
Documents-17.iso (Bazarloader)
Invoice_pdf_1.iso (IcedID)
The ZIP file contains an ISO image file with the following name documents-04-106.iso. Note that the following ISO image file name pattern was used for all the files that we have analyzed:
C:\Windows\System32\rundll32.exe settings.dll,IternalJob
cmd.exe /c start rundll32 neqw.dll,IternalJob<crlf>rundll32.exe advpack.dll,RegisterOCX sysctl.exe

Kindra Cantrell<crlf>April 14, 2022<crlf>12 minutes, 22 seconds read
Kindra Cantrell<crlf>April 14, 2022<crlf>12 minutes, 22 seconds read
Meet CyOps Complementary MDR Team
Meet CyOps Complementary MDR Team
Meet CyOps Complementary MDR Team

The Orion team is constantly monitoring BumbleBee and the IAB groups activities closely and analyzing them to better understand their motivation. As we learn more, we will publish our findings and artifacts to share additional insights for BumbleBee infection to ransomware post-attack chain.

From our initial analysis, BumbleBee is a custom new loader that is used by different IAB groups. This malware was observed injecting Cobalt Strike shellcodes in memory and using several tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) in order to compromise the victims environment.

We noticed a new trend in Initial Access Brokers (IAB) tactics to gain access to their victims machines. Initial Access Brokers refers to a cybercrime group that specializes in gaining initial access to organizations for the sole purpose of offering it to other threat actor groups. The trend started earlier this year and our team recently spotted their new BumbleBee campaign.
On April 12, 2022, the BumbleBee IAB group was spotted using IMG file format in addition to ISO file format.

In most of the cases, weve seen that during different IR cases, the campaigns escalated to full-blown ransomware attacks. We believe that IAB groups work and collaborate with ransomware affiliates like CONTI, LockBit, AvosLocker, and more. For example, we observed an IcedID infection that leads to CONTI ransomware attack (Shelob Moonlight)..

Weve seen Living Off the Land Binaries (LOLBins) execution with rundll32, which allows threat actors to avoid defenses. BumbleBee also creates a scheduled task on the compromised host for persistence and executes a Visual Basic script via the scheduled task. The IAB relies on the user (victim) execution to execute the BumbleBee payload by luring the victim to mount an ISO image file and click on a Windows shortcut (LNK) file.
In this post, we will cover what this campaign is, and how the IAB distributes the BumbleBee malware and its TTPs. We will also explain each TTP according to the MITRE ATT&CK model, and its purpose.

Weve seen Living Off the Land Binaries (LOLBins) execution with rundll32, which allows threat actors to avoid defenses. BumbleBee also creates a scheduled task on the compromised host for persistence and executes a Visual Basic script via the scheduled task. The IAB relies on the user (victim) execution to execute the BumbleBee payload by luring the victim to mount an ISO image file and click on a Windows shortcut (LNK) file.

Orion found a high number of targeted companies based in the US with the following distribution method that delivers the BumbleBee malware: Spear phishing email > URL Link (TransferXL, TransferNow, WeTransfer) > Zipped ISO > ISO (contains the LNK file and the BumbleBee payload).
Below is an example of what the ZIP file from the TransferXL link looks like.
TransferXL legitimate public storage services
The BumbleBee payload was delivered via a spear phishing email that was sent from a spoofed email address. The email contains a URL link to the legitimate public storage service, TransferXL.
ZIP file download from TransferXL
Spear phishing email with a link to TransferXL

Orion found a high number of targeted companies based in the US with the following distribution method that delivers the BumbleBee malware: Spear phishing email > URL Link (TransferXL, TransferNow, WeTransfer) > Zipped ISO > ISO (contains the LNK file and the BumbleBee payload).

Orion found a high number of targeted companies based in the US with the following distribution method that delivers the BumbleBee malware: Spear phishing email > URL Link (TransferXL, TransferNow, WeTransfer) > Zipped ISO > ISO (contains the LNK file and the BumbleBee payload).

Weve handled several incident response (IR) cases where threat actors distributed BumbleBee malware. After the initial infection, the threat actors inject Cobalt Strike shellcode in memory and execute discovery commands to collect info about the victims network. We believe that threat actors performed this data collection in order to execute the next stage of the infection.
The next stage is probably related to ransomware operations. Were still investigating IR cases in order to find conclusive evidence that the next stage delivers ransomware.
In this section, we will cover some interesting indicators and artifacts that highlighted the BumbleBee actions and heuristics. These artifacts also help us to identify the BumbleBee malware.
After unpacking the BumbleBee loader and by searching in the metadata of the unpacked payload, we identified BumbleBees internal name, LdrAddx64.dll, and two export functions IternalJob and SetPath.
Other anti-VM artifacts were found after unpacking, as can be seen in the following strings:
Bumblebees internal name and the export functions names in the memory
After unpacking the BumbleBee loader and by searching in the metadata of the unpacked payload, we identified BumbleBees internal name, LdrAddx64.dll, and two export functions IternalJob and SetPath.
We analyzed the payload binary and noticed that this payload is responsible for communicating with BumbleBees C2 server:
C:\Windows\System32\rundll32.exe settings.dll,IternalJob
After unpacking the BumbleBee loader and by searching in the metadata of the unpacked payload, we identified BumbleBees internal name, LdrAddx64.dll, and two export functions IternalJob and SetPath.
cmd.exe /c start rundll32 neqw.dll,IternalJob<crlf>rundll32.exe advpack.dll,RegisterOCX sysctl.exe
After unpacking the BumbleBee loader and by searching in the metadata of the unpacked payload, we identified BumbleBees internal name, LdrAddx64.dll, and two export functions IternalJob and SetPath.
BumbleBee internal name, export functions, and TimeDateStamp
Payloads internal name and TimeDateStamp
By inspecting the unpacked BumbleBee sections, we discovered that the .data section contains two executables:
PEStudio shows the unpacked Bumblebee section and highlighted the .data section
PEStudio showing the payloads metadata
PEStudio showing the payloads strings that could be related to process injection
Hex-Editor shows 3 MZ headers: the first one is the Bumblebee, and the other two are additional payloads
We extracted the two hidden payloads from the .data section by using Hex-Editor tool:

We found a few interesting functions in the payload strings indicating that this payload has process injection capabilities. For example, CreateProcess, NtWriteVirtualMemory, CreateRemoteThread,and WinExec.

We found a few interesting functions in the payload strings indicating that this payload has process injection capabilities. For example, CreateProcess, NtWriteVirtualMemory, CreateRemoteThread,and WinExec.

We found a few interesting functions in the payload strings indicating that this payload has process injection capabilities. For example, CreateProcess, NtWriteVirtualMemory, CreateRemoteThread,and WinExec.

In most of the cases, weve seen that during different IR cases, the campaigns escalated to full-blown ransomware attacks. We believe that IAB groups work and collaborate with ransomware affiliates like CONTI, LockBit, AvosLocker, and more. For example, we observed an IcedID infection that leads to CONTI ransomware attack (Shelob Moonlight)..

In most of the cases, weve seen that during different IR cases, the campaigns escalated to full-blown ransomware attacks. We believe that IAB groups work and collaborate with ransomware affiliates like CONTI, LockBit, AvosLocker, and more. For example, we observed an IcedID infection that leads to CONTI ransomware attack (Shelob Moonlight)..

The Orion team is constantly monitoring BumbleBee and the IAB groups activities closely and analyzing them to better understand their motivation. As we learn more, we will publish our findings and artifacts to share additional insights for BumbleBee infection to ransomware post-attack chain.
We hope this was helpful. And remember to check our blog page and follow us on social media to see when we publish updates.

Were expecting to see more malware campaigns that will use the ISO delivery method in the near future. So, stay vigilant.

As a final note, wed like to share these indicators of compromise with you.

titles: By: Max Malyutin Orion Threat Research Team Leader

sentences: Orion, Cynets Threat Research and Intelligence team, spotted a new malware campaign in the wild: BumbleBee.
Wondering whats going on? Let us fill you in.

We noticed a new trend in Initial Access Brokers (IAB) tactics to gain access to their victims machines. Initial Access Brokers refers to a cybercrime group that specializes in gaining initial access to organizations for the sole purpose of offering it to other threat actor groups. The trend started earlier this year and our team recently spotted their new BumbleBee campaign.

We expected these groups to change the initial access methods. We believe there is a direct relation to the changes Microsoft applied recently to the default policy in their Office products: Macros from the internet will be blocked by default in Office and Excel 4.0 (XLM) macros are disabled by default. These changes impact IABs because they have been abusing Office documents with malicious macros for years.
It appears that theyve come up with a plan B.
Below youll see the legitimate public storage site, which leads the victim to the link to the malicious file.

From this step, threat actors rely on the victim (user) interaction with the ISO image file. The threat actors use a masquerading technique by setting the LNK file icon to be a folder icon in order to lure the victim to click on the LNK file:
Copy of the BumbleBee DLL to %Programdata% directory
We found that the threat actors used the AdFind tool to enumerate and map the victims network. The ADFind tool was found in the %ProgramData% directory.

We have other artifacts from different IR cases, where we have observed the following activity. The screenshot below shows an event that detected a creation of a payload in the %ProgramData%\{Random} directory the DLL payload is a copy of the initial BumbleBee loader that executed by Rundll32 from the ISO image file:
After the initial execution, the BumbleBee DLL is copied to the %programdata%/{RandomDir} directory. In addition to the DLL, a VBS script is also dropped to the same directory:
After the initial execution, the BumbleBee DLL is copied to the %programdata%/{RandomDir} directory. In addition to the DLL, a VBS script is also dropped to the same directory:
cmd.exe /c start rundll32 neqw.dll,IternalJob<crlf>rundll32.exe advpack.dll,RegisterOCX sysctl.exe
cmd.exe /c start rundll32 neqw.dll,IternalJob<crlf>rundll32.exe advpack.dll,RegisterOCX sysctl.exe
Strings from the Bumblebee loader show the WMI Win32_Process execution
List of strings that are related to VMware and VirtualBox
One of the anti-VM checks is related to the VirtualBox product:
Check for lpWindowName if matches VirtualBox
Check for lpWindowName if matches VirtualBox

BumbleBee checks whether certain user names reside in the victims machine by comparing against a hardcoded list of user names. This allows BumbleBee to detect sandboxes and labs that are used for malware analysis:
List of hardcoded usernames which are related to sandboxes and labs
